article.title: Bosonic topological phases of matter: bulk-boundary correspondence, SPT invariants and gauging

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows a triangulation of a three-torus. How many 3-simplices are there in this triangulation?

This figure shows a triangulation of a 2-torus with specific fluxes 'a' and 'b' along the two cycles. What does Dijkgraaf-Witten theory labelled by H<sup>2</sup><sub>group</sub>(G, U(1)) associate to this assignment 'A'?
choices: A U(1) phase c(a, b) + c(b, a)
A U(1) phase c(a, b)/c(b, a)

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates a flat Z<sub>n</sub> gauge field configuration on a 3-simplex. What do the variables 'a', 'b', and 'c' represent in this configuration?
choices: The coboundary operator acting on the edges.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents a triangulation of a three-torus.  Compared to calculations on a 4-torus (T<sup>4</sup>) and a Lens space times a circle (L(n, 1) × S<sup>1</sup>), what is the advantage of performing computations on this triangulation?
choices: Calculations on this triangulation are more complex but conceptually similar to those on T<sup>4</sup> and L(n, 1) × S<sup>1</sup>.
Calculations on this triangulation are much simpler and unrelated to those on T<sup>4</sup> and L(n, 1) × S<sup>1</sup>.
Calculations on this triangulation are simpler and dimensionally reduced versions of those on T<sup>4</sup> and L(n, 1) × S<sup>1</sup>.
Calculations on this triangulation are identical to those on T<sup>4</sup> and L(n, 1) × S<sup>1</sup>.
